title: J&J Vaccine Highly Effective Against Delta Variant in South African Trial
summary: Study finds J&J vaccine has an efficacy of up to 71% against hospitalization from the highly contagious strain. Johnson & Johnson 's Covid-19 vaccine is highly effective in preventing severe disease and death from the Delta variant, according to data released Friday from a clinical trial in South Africa.

title: United Airlines, Square, Spirit: Stocks That Defined the Week
summary: Seven major companies' stocks moved on the news this past week. United Airlines Holdings Inc.

title: Biden's Eviction Ban Goes Back to Court
summary: The plaintiffs have fun quoting the White House against itself.. The Justice Department on Friday filed its emergency defense of President Biden's latest national eviction ban, and it's almost enough to make you feel bad for the poor lawyer who had to sign it. Mr. Biden justified the lawless order as a way to buy time, and the attorneys don't bring an argument that's any better.

title: Brian Brooks Quits as CEO of Crypto Exchange Binance.US
summary: Former regulator is leaving after just three months on the job. Brian Brooks, a former top U.S. banking regulator, resigned as chief executive of cryptocurrency exchange Binance.US, just three months after taking the job.

title: Amtrak's $66 Billion Ticket
summary: The government can't run a railroad, but it sure can subsidize one.. The Senate's $1 trillion infrastructure bill is leaving the station with $66 billion in new subsidies for Amtrak and passenger rail, but nobody should think this freight car of cash will end the government railroad's problems.

title: So Much for 'Fully Paid For'
summary: The infrastructure bill's financing is full of gimmicks, as expected.. One claim about the Senate's infrastructure bill is that it would be, as the authors said, "fully paid for." The Congressional Budget Office rudely blew apart that myth on Thursday, not that the authors seem to care.

title: A Summer Employment Surge
summary: Did the end of enhanced jobless benefits lead to a boost in job entrants?. Politicians take credit for the sunrise, so naturally President Biden crowed on Friday about the cheery 943,000 increase in jobs in the Labor Department's July report. That's politics. But on the economic merits he should also be thanking the 26 states that have ended the $300 federal unemployment bonus and other pandemic benefit enhancements earlier than he wanted.

title: What to Read This Week
summary: Presidential pals, the real story of pioneering women, Ha Jin's novel of a singer in exile, murder in Dublin, ballet school suspense and more..

title: Gov. Cuomo Accuser Files Criminal Complaint
summary: Complaint involves alleged groping incident included in New York attorney general's report. ALBANY, N. Y.-One of Gov. Andrew Cuomo's executive assistants filed a criminal complaint with the Albany County sheriff's office alleging the governor groped her during an encounter at the Executive Mansion last year, the sheriff said.

title: 'First Friends' Review: Party of Two
summary: Careerists and flatterers hover around the Oval Office-but a president needs a ready ear and honest counsel.. Wealth and power bring admirers aplenty, but few friends. "It's lonely at the top" is a cliché that happens to be true. But unlike other wealthy and powerful people, high-level politicians don't have the luxury of insulating themselves from the crowd. They are required by their position to cultivate allies and supporters at every level of society and in all parts of the country. They are surrounded much of the time by admiring careerists and prestige-seekers who laugh at all their jokes and feign interest in their welfare, but what they need are a few friends-people whose affection doesn't depend on political office and whose counsel isn't rooted in self-interest.

title: WhatsApp Rejects Apple's Approach on Exploitative Images of Children
summary: 'This approach introduces something very concerning into the world,' says the head of the Facebook platform. Facebook Inc.'s WhatsApp messaging unit blasted Apple Inc.'s plan to monitor sexually exploitative images of children on iPhones as bad for privacy, opening a new front in the battle between two of the world's biggest tech companies.

title: FAA Chief Urges Care to Avoid Safety Risks as Airlines Ramp Up
summary: The aviation-safety regulator sends a letter to carriers pointing out potential risks. U.S. air-safety regulators want airlines to stay on top of potential safety issues like employee fatigue as carriers race to keep up with a surge in demand for flights.

title: Biden Administration Extends Pause on Student-Loan Repayments Until Jan. 31
summary: Biden administration again extends moratorium on federal loans, this time until Jan. 31. WASHINGTON-The Biden administration is extending a moratorium on federal student-loan payments through early 2022.

title: United Airlines to Require All U.S. Employees to Get Covid-19 Vaccines
summary: Airline is the first major carrier to mandate all workers get shots. United Airlines Holdings Inc. will require its 67,000 U.S. employees to be vaccinated this fall, the first major airline to take this step as the Delta variant drives a nationwide increase in Covid-19 infections.

title: U.S. Economy Added 943,000 Jobs in July
summary: Robust job growth last month reflects a strong labor market ahead of the Delta variant threat. A strengthening U.S. labor market added cushion to the economic recovery in July ahead of the surge in cases of the coronavirus's Delta variant, with employers creating jobs at the best pace in nearly a year and the unemployment rate falling sharply.

title: Delta Variant Disrupts Rebound in Travel and Leisure
summary: Travel agencies, hotels, cruise operators, show organizers see some impact from rising Covid-19 cases and want to show they can operate amid virus. Americans returned to the road, skies and stadiums this year. But lately, the great reopening has lost some momentum.

title: Michael Calvey Given 5½-Year Suspended Sentence by Russian Court
summary: U.S. private-equity investor's sentencing caps court case watched closely by global business community for more than two years. MOSCOW-A Russian court handed American private-equity investor Michael Calvey a suspended sentence of 5½ years for embezzlement, a day after a judge ruled that he was guilty in a case that galvanized the international business community for more than two years.

title: Why I'm Suing Over My Employer's Vaccine Mandate
summary: I have natural immunity, so there's no justification for a coercive violation of my bodily autonomy.. In a few weeks I will begin my 24th year as a law professor at George Mason University. Last year I volunteered to teach in person, even though I'm in my 50s. Teaching law is my job and I owe my students my best. I also knew I could do it safely. During the spring of 2020 I contracted and recovered from Covid-19, which I later confirmed through a positive antibody test. Multiple positive antibody tests have since confirmed that I continue to have a robust level of immune protection.

title: 'The Gallery of Miracles and Madness' Review: Triumph of the Ill
summary: Surrealists saw the artwork of mental patients as inspiration for their own. Nazi authorities saw both as diseased.. Whenever I read about Hitler's youthful dream of becoming an artist, I imagine an alternate history in which the Academy of Fine Arts Vienna accepted his application to study there. But the august academy said no to the future Führer not once but twice, and Hitler himself declared that the academy's rebuff struck like "a bolt from the blue."

title: Does the U.S. Want the Lab-Leak Truth?
summary: It's hard to see political upside from anything but intelligence agency shoulder-shrugging.. Independently in 1978, two groups in New York City and Germany came to the same conclusion: The previous year's flu was so genetically similar to a variant last seen in the early 1950s that it could only have started from a stored lab specimen. The obvious candidates: China or Russia, in whose border regions the virus first manifested itself.

title: JP Morgan Wins Permission for Full Control of a Securities Business in China
summary: Wall Street giant gets more market access; can offer a full range of investment and corporate banking, securities services, asset management.

title: The Asian Art Museum: Full of Art With a Past, Not of the Past
summary: The San Francisco institution caps its expansion and upgrading with a new exhibition.. San Francisco

title: Enigmatic Isolation
summary: Mysteries abound in Edward Hopper's 'Western Motel,' which invites viewers to craft their own story about what's happening..

title: Cathie Wood, Meme-Stock Champion Who Bet Big on Tesla and Bitcoin, Stands Her Ground
summary: Resume Subscription. Fans of fund manager Cathie Wood have built websites that track her every investment move. They sell T-shirts with her picture in the style of the Barack Obama "Hope" poster and with the ticker symbol of her flagship exchange-traded fund, ARK Innovation. On social media, they call her "Mamma Cathie," "Aunt Cathie" and, in South Korea, "Money Tree."

title: Amazon to Require Masks for Warehouse Workers as Delta Variant Surges
summary: The new policy starts Monday, and will include locations where local law doesn't require face coverings to combat Covid-19. Amazon.com Inc. said all workers at its hundreds of U.S. warehouses will have to wear masks starting Monday, expanding a more limited requirement in response to the resurgent Covid-19 threat posed by the Delta variant.

title: Democrats Reboot Stalled Election-Law Push
summary: Negotiators hope to unite party while also bringing some Republicans on board. WASHINGTON-Democratic lawmakers were working to finalize whittled-down elections legislation as they reached Friday's anniversary of the 1965 Voting Rights Act, with negotiators saying they were close on a measure intended to override state voting restrictions by setting minimum standards for accessing the ballot.

title: Stocks Close Mostly Higher After Jobs Report
summary: Investors weigh earnings surge against risks posed by Delta variant, Chinese tech crackdown. U.S. stocks mostly rose on Friday after a better-than-expected jobs report showed the economy continuing to rebound but raised fresh questions about Federal Reserve policy.

title: Covid-19 Medical Stockpiles Weigh on Cardinal Health Results
summary: The distributor has built up inventories of N95 masks and other personal protective equipment amid an uncertain path for the coronavirus pandemic. Stockpiles of masks, gloves and other personal protective equipment are weighing on Cardinal Health Inc.'s finances as the distributor copes with supply-chain strains and an uncertain trajectory for the coronavirus pandemic.

title: U.S. Says Drone Fragments on Israeli-Linked Tanker Point to Iran's Role in Attack
summary: EU ambassador says 'all available evidence' shows Iran behind deadly attack in Arabian Sea; Tehran denies responsibility. WASHINGTON-The U.S. military said Friday that drone fragments recovered from an Israeli-linked merchant vessel damaged in a fatal attack in the Arabian Sea last week prove Iran was behind the incident.

title: U.S. Government Bond Yields Rose After Jobs Report
summary: Signs of healing labor market seen easing concerns about economic outlook. U.S. government bond yields rose Friday after Labor Department data showed the unemployment rate declined to its lowest level since the pandemic took hold.

title: Why Some 'Jeopardy!' Fans Are Up in Arms About Potential Host Mike Richards
summary: After reports that the game-show's executive producer is in talks to become permanent host, fans are raising questions about the months-long process. Answer: This "Jeopardy!" insider was revealed to be a leading candidate for the role of full-time host of the game show, bringing climactic drama to an eight-month search process that has roiled the trivia institution and divided fans.

title: Animal Rescue (Saturday Crossword, August 7)
Turning Points (Saturday Variety Puzzle, August 7)
The Scientific Thrill of the Charcoal Grill
summary: The scent of burning briquettes on summer evenings are a pleasant byproduct of a super-efficient way of generating heat. Physicist Helen Czerski explores the complex science behind familiar phenomena. Read more columns here.

title: Nasdaq's Board-Diversity Proposal Wins SEC Approval
summary: Agency backs plan to set minimum targets for composition of listed companies' directors. Nasdaq Inc.'s push for greater diversity on corporate boards cleared a key hurdle, as regulators approved the exchange operator's proposal to include gender and race in its listing rules.

title: Levi's Leaves Board of Fashion Coalition at Center of China Controversy
summary: Jeans maker stands down from Better Cotton Initiative's leadership amid debate over coalition's response to alleged human-rights abuses in Xinjiang. Levi Strauss & Co. is leaving the board of a high-profile fashion-industry coalition, according to people familiar with the matter, in a move that presents a leadership gap in a group divided over how to respond to alleged human-rights abuses in China's cotton-rich Xinjiang region.

title: Taliban Seize Capital of Afghanistan's Nimroz Province and Kill Official in Kabul
summary: Resume Subscription. KABUL-The Taliban seized the capital of an Afghan province along the Iranian and Pakistani borders on Friday, the first such takeover since the insurgents launched an offensive to take advantage of the U.S. troop withdrawal.

title: Great British Cheese: A Full-Flavored Guide
summary: Farmhouse cheese-making is back in England-a robust tradition there for the tasting. These are the wedges and wheels to try.. WHEN I SAW the title of Katie Quinn's book "Cheese, Wine, and Bread," I presumed the cheese part would play out in France. That country's wheels are always held up as the ne plus ultra. But Ms. Quinn chose Britain to begin her exploration of fermentation's role in making food delicious.

title: Unvaccinated More Than Twice as Likely to Get Covid-19 Again, CDC Says
summary: Vaccination cuts the risk of catching Covid-19 again by more than half, study suggests. Unvaccinated people are more than twice as likely to be reinfected with Covid-19 than people who are fully vaccinated, a new study suggests, underscoring the importance of vaccines in containing the pandemic.

title: Covid-19 Threatens to Blow Up Law Firms' Intense Office Culture
summary: Lawyers have spent more time in the office than many other professionals during the pandemic. Now they're demanding more work from home.. Between 100-hour workweeks and all-nighters at the office, young lawyers climbing the partner track have long been expected to put in copious amounts of face time.

title: What's With the Birkenstock Craze? It's Not Just About Comfort.
summary: Whether you find Birkenstocks stylishly orthopedic or unfortunately clunky, fashion insiders of both sexes remain enthralled by them. Here, the secret to their enduring popularity.. WHEN LOVERN PASCUAL and November Ang got married last month, more than one guest confronted the newlyweds with playful variations on this question: "You're wearing Birks at your wedding? Are you kidding?" The couple was not kidding. Ms. Pascual opted for an ivory pair of the German shoe brand's two-strap Arizona, while Ms. Ang went with the chocolate-brown Yara, a sandal whose straps wrap almost elegantly around the big toe.

title: Mixed Doubles
summary: A Brief History of the often surprising, occasionally counterintuitive collaborations for Birkenstock 1774. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: JPMorgan Makes Masks Mandatory to Combat Delta-Variant Spread
summary: Move is another sign that the fast-spreading Delta variant is hampering corporate attempts to return to normal. JPMorgan Chase & Co. has reinstituted a mask mandate for its U.S. employees, vaccinated or not, another sign that the fast-spreading Delta variant is hampering corporate attempts to return to normal.

title: Could a Conservative Replace Gavin Newsom?
summary: A quixotic effort to recall California's governor is suddenly gaining steam. And libertarian radio host Larry Elder is the front-runner.. What are the odds that California would elect a conservative Republican governor in the 2020s? Slim to none, one might have said. But that was before Larry Elder entered the room.

title: Why Orthodox Jews Are Leaving Brooklyn for Florida
summary: Good jobs, cheap housing and a unique school choice program have many families heading south.. What would motivate a Hasidic rabbi and his followers to leave a Brooklyn enclave where they've lived for generations and establish a quickly growing community in Wimauma, Fla., a semi-rural area near Tampa Bay?

title: Maersk Buys Two Logistics Operators, Flags More Deals
summary: Deals valued at nearly $1 billion combined come as Maersk, the world's largest container shipper, reports strong earnings. A.P. Moller-Maersk A/S reported robust earnings helped by a frenetic global shipping market, announced it bought two e-commerce logistics companies together valued at nearly $1 billion, and mapped out more, potentially larger acquisitions.

title: Climate AI Startups Offer Businesses Shelter From Inclement Weather Risk
summary: There have been eight extreme events in the U.S. with losses exceeding $1 billion so far in 2021. A cold snap in Texas earlier this year shut down refineries and chemical plants. Drought in Taiwan continues to put pressure on semiconductor manufacturing capacity. And in the U.S. Pacific Northwest, businesses are still recovering from losses as a result of recent record high temperatures.

title: Honoring the Past With Art and Tears
summary: With a style of 'weeping realism' often based on photos, California-based Hung Liu evokes the crucible of China's Cultural Revolution. As a teenager in 1960s China, Hung Liu knew that family photos could be dangerous. During the Cultural Revolution, having an elite or educated family background could lead to prison, and Ms. Liu was the granddaughter of a scholar; worse, her father had fought against the Communists. So family members saved a handful of pictures and burned the rest. Diaries, too, went up in smoke.

title: Indian Girl's Alleged Rape and Killing Sets Off Protests in Delhi
summary: Mother's accusations have renewed anger in the country over sexual violence and the treatment of members of lower castes. NEW DELHI-An Indian mother's allegations that her 9-year-old daughter was raped and killed have set off days of protests in the capital and renewed anger in the country over sexual violence and the mistreatment of Indians who belong to the country's lower castes.

title: Producer Marcia Nasatir Broke Into Hollywood's Boys' Club
summary: Former United Artists executive, who died at 95, helped green-light blockbuster films. When Marcia Nasatir became United Artists' first female production vice president, her job title depended on whom you asked. Her boss called her "our woman vice president." Studios called her role "Marcia's job."

title: Arkansas Judge Blocks State From Enforcing Mask Mandate Ban
summary: Ban challenged by two lawsuits, including one from a district where more than 800 staff and students are quarantining because of a Covid outbreak. LITTLE ROCK, Ark.-An Arkansas judge on Friday temporarily blocked the state from enforcing its ban on mask mandates after lawmakers left the prohibition in place despite a rising number of Covid-19 cases and hospitalizations.

title: Dennis Prager on YouTube's Record of Censorship
summary: It interferes with free speech about Covid and, as PragerU has discovered, so much more.. Regarding Susan Wojcicki's "Free Speech and Corporate Responsibility Can Coexist Online" (op-ed, Aug. 2): My sense is that Ms. Wojcicki, the CEO of YouTube, is sincere and well-intentioned but has no idea how much damage to free speech YouTube, its owner, Google, and all the other tech giants cause. Examples of censored speech on Google and YouTube could fill an issue of The Wall Street Journal.

title: The NCAA's Student-Athlete Fiction
summary: They are admitted to play sports. Pay them to do so and dispense with all the fake majors.. I applaud Prof. Thomas Miller Jr.'s attempt, in extending scholarships, to reconcile the obvious incompatibility of a traditional four-year academic education in a rigorous discipline with the fiction of the student-athlete ("Student-Athletes Deserve 10-Year Scholarships," op-ed, July 29).

title: Noonan Asks Wrong Questions About Jan. 6 Riot
summary: The story of the Capitol Police hasn't been told, and Pelosi's committee won't tell it.. Peggy Noonan thinks Jan. 6 was extraordinary ("The Jan. 6 Committee Carries History's Weight," Declarations, July 31), but in many ways it wasn't. Like almost all riots in the past year, a demonstration that created a crowd-control problem was bungled by elected officials and police leadership, and it escalated to a riot. A desire to avoid bad optics and have light footprints resulted in terrible police-staffing and deployment decisions, as well as the refusal to allow officers to use proper protective equipment and riot-control tactics. The same politicians then either minimized or condemned the rioters' outrageous behavior, depending on their positions on the political spectrum. All sadly ordinary.

title: Blaming the Government, Again
summary: The U.K.'s recent epidemiological efforts are worth praising.. Holman W. Jenkins, Jr.'s "Maybe With Delta the CDC Will Learn to Count" (Business World, July 31) details how some U.S. government agencies and much of the media are missing important epidemiological information about the rise of the Delta variant. But after doing so persuasively, it suddenly veers off to criticize its own sources.

title: The Road to Hell Is Paved With Governments' Good Intentions
summary: From Amtrak to ObamaCare, you'll find poor design and implementation.. In his column "The Coming Eviction Crisis" (Politics & Ideas, Aug. 4), William A. Galston writes, apparently with no sense of irony, that the rental-assistance program in President Biden's March Covid relief bill "is a classic case of good intentions undermined by poor design and implementation." But isn't that the definition of a federal government program, from Amtrak to ObamaCare?

title: AIG Marks Major Progress
summary: Investors already know that a lot of capital return is likely coming, but the core property-and-casualty business is doing quite well, too. American International Group is looking like more than just a breakup story.

title: Dissident Novelist Alaa Al Aswany
summary: In a new novel, Egypt's celebrated dissident assesses the complicated aftermath of revolution.. Alaa Al Aswany, one of the most renowned novelists of the Arab world, almost gave up writing. After Egypt's state publisher rejected his first two novels in the 1990s, he published them himself, earning critical praise but few readers. When the state, which monopolizes book distribution, rejected him a third time, in 1998, Mr. Al Aswany felt "humiliated," he says. He decided to release one last novel through a small private publisher in his hometown of Cairo, then abandon his literary aspirations and move to New Zealand-because it was "very far," he says.

title: SEC Brings, Settles First Case in Crypto-Linked DeFi Sector
summary: Two men agree to cease-and-desist order and to return profits reaped by using decentralized-finance technology. WASHINGTON--The Securities and Exchange Commission brought and settled its first case against a firm in the so-called decentralized-finance or DeFi sector, the latest sign of intensifying regulatory scrutiny for cryptocurrency markets.

title: 'New Women in the Old West' Review: Pioneers of Progress
summary: Homesteaders, teachers, ranchers-and champions of women's suffrage, who won the right to vote in the West ahead of the East.. 'Go West, young man, go West and grow up with the country." Substitute the word "woman" for "man," and this famous exhortation-attributed to newspaper editor Horace Greeley in 1865-could serve as the epigraph for Winifred Gallagher's book on the forgotten women of the American frontier.

title: 'A Song Everlasting' Review: A Voice in Exile
summary: A tenor leaves Beijing for a freer life in America-but sacrifices his career to do so.. The fictional character of the troubled artist, so often plagued by introspective maunderings, can make even a sympathetic reader long to escape. Into Stella Gibbons's masterpiece "Cold Comfort Farm," perhaps, which has the sublime Mr. Mybug, a caricature of D.H. Lawrence, declaring "I'm a queer moody brute . . . but there's something there if you cah to dig for it." (The heroine, sensible girl, doesn't.) Then again, there are all those triumphs of artistic portrayal. Think of Julian Barnes's "The Noise of Time," for example, which concerns Dmitri Shostakovich's life under Stalin's terror and has the composer insisting that "art no more belongs to the People and the Party than it once belonged to the aristocracy and the patron." Now, nearly nine decades after Shostakovich's ordeal, the artist at the heart of Ha Jin's novel "A Song Everlasting" (Pantheon, 336 pages, $28), to his great cost, reaffirms that proclamation.

title: 'Burning Man' Review: Extremely D.H. Lawrence
summary: In a literary world full of factional fighting, Lawrence was 'the sole member of his own party.'. Of all the countless anecdotes told of D.H. Lawrence (1885-1930), my absolute favorite takes in the musician-cum-critic Cecil Gray, Lawrence's neighbor during his World War I-era sojourn in Cornwall. The story goes that Gray, hard at work one morning in his remote cottage, heard a knock at the door. It opened to reveal the author of "The Rainbow"-bearded, beady-eyed and intent-who without preamble demanded: "How long is it, Gray, since you have loved me?" What Gray is supposed to have said in return is not recorded; shortly afterward Lawrence could be seen making his way back over the fields to the house he shared with his recently acquired wife, the former Frieda von Richthofen.

title: Former Enron Adviser Praises 'Accounting Gimmicks'
summary: Will Paul Krugman of the New York Times never learn?. These days truth seems to be getting much stranger than fiction. Now a former adviser to Enron, which collapsed in an infamous 2001 accounting scandal that sent various of the firm's executives and bankers to prison, has published an astounding endorsement of "budget chicanery."

title: Walmart Gives Bonuses, Raises to Keep Warehouse Workers
summary: Most U.S. warehouses give staff extra payments and temporary raises as retailer prepares for holidays. Walmart Inc. is offering special bonuses to many warehouse employees to work every hour they are scheduled and, in some cases giving temporary pay raises, as the country's biggest retailer ramps up for the holiday shopping season with a tight labor market and stretched supply chains.

title: Democrat Conor Lamb Jumps Into Crowded Pennsylvania Senate Race
summary: Contest for Keystone State in 2022 is seen as critical to control of Senate. Democratic Rep. Conor Lamb jumped into the race to succeed retiring Republican Sen. Pat Toomey of Pennsylvania, entering a competitive and crowded primary field in a state where President Biden eked out a narrow victory over incumbent Donald Trump last year.

title: Israeli Military Strikes Lebanon After Hezbollah Rocket Attack
summary: Neither side reported any injuries from the exchange of fire, which comes at a sensitive time for both countries. Israel's military said it struck areas in southern Lebanon after a barrage of rockets were fired across the border by the Iran-allied militant and political group Hezbollah, marking an escalation of tensions between the two neighbors.

title: Fiction: 'Paris Is a Party, Paris Is a Ghost' Review
summary: David Hoon Kim's novel tracks a student's sojourn in a spectral City of Light.. In Mavis Gallant's great 1953 short story "The Other Paris," a woman working in an American government agency sheds her romantic expectations of the City of Light for decidedly shabbier realities: a boring office job, lousy weather, crumbling apartment buildings and penniless war refugees. Hers is the expat counter-story that has always sat beside the French fairy tale, in which self-discovery is a long process of disenchantment. David Hoon Kim's debut, "Paris Is a Party, Paris Is a Ghost" (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, 240 pages, $26), is the latest installment in the genre, a novel preoccupied with the very 21st-century topics of identity, alienation and trauma.

title: Forgot How to Navigate the Airport Like a Pro? Road Warriors Turn Rookie
summary: Business travelers, accustomed to ruling the skies, forget the basics; 'So embarrassing'. For more than five years, Jessica Ridlen treated business travel as a ritual. The biotechnology executive kept a go-bag at the ready, refilled her mini toiletry stash regularly and boasted two sets of every charging cord.

title: Lawyer Opened Lines for Phone Company Breakup
summary: Howard Trienens shaped AT&T business separation and law firm's growth. Howard Trienens, a lawyer who guided the breakup of telecommunications colossus AT&T Corp. during the 1980s, excelled at distilling complex problems into solutions his clients could support.

title: Space Race, Nvidia and IBM: What to Watch When the Market Opens
summary: Stock futures are higher after Monday's slide on Wall Street. To the moon! Well, not quite, but into space at least today for Jeff Bezos, the billionaire baron of ecommerce. Also not going to the moon is Amazon stock, though it is 0.3% up premarket on Tuesday morning.

title: 2021 Ford Bronco 4x4: Loaded with Options, Primed for Adventure
summary: The all new Ford Bronco has been repackaged for an emerging 4x4 heavy-duty 'adventure vehicle' segment. Dan Neil takes one off-roading.. AMERICA HAS BEEN waiting for the Ford Bronco cake to be baked so long that now, standing here with the knife, I hardly know where to cut first. This beguiling, pomo-retro reimagining of the American classic (1966-1977) suffered a lengthy failure to launch due to the Covid crisis and the industrywide chip shortage. The situation left nearly 200,000 panting buckaroos holding their reservations. All better now, though.

title: Jobs Report Risks Different Kind of Taper Tantrum
summary: Robust jobs recovery could lead to pressure on the Fed to hasten a normalization of policy. Leave it to Joe Manchin to know which way the wind is blowing.

title: Escaping the Efficiency Trap-and Finding Some Peace of Mind
summary: The more productive we are, the more pressure we feel. It's time to break the busyness cycle.. Certain forms of busyness can be delightful. Who wouldn't want to live in Busytown, the setting of the iconic 1960s children's books by the American illustrator Richard Scarry? His grocer cats and firefighting pigs are certainly busy. Nobody in Busytown is idle-or if they are, they're carefully hidden from view by the authorities, Pyongyang-style. What they aren't, though, is overwhelmed. They exude the cheery self-possession of cats and pigs who have plenty to do but also every confidence that their tasks will fit snugly into the hours available-whereas we live with the constant anxiety of fearing, or knowing for certain, that ours won't.

title: 'The Irish Assassins' Review: The Terror in Phoenix Park
summary: When Frederick Cavendish arrived in Dublin to take up his part in Britain's rule of Ireland, a conspiracy was waiting.. On a soft spring evening in Dublin, in 1882, two distinguished gentlemen strolled up the broad avenue that bisects Phoenix Park, a vast expanse of greenery in Ireland's capital city. One was the newly appointed chief secretary of Ireland, Lord Frederick Cavendish-the younger son of the Duke of Devonshire and a relation, by marriage, of the prime minister-who had arrived that morning to take up his post. The other was the permanent under secretary, Thomas Burke, a career civil servant. Burke had been in office for more than a dozen years; one resident of the park, a child named Winston Churchill, later remembered that Burke had given him a toy drum.

title: China Aims to Export 2 Billion Covid-19 Vaccines This Year
summary: Commitment expands Chinese diplomatic effort to help developing nations, as Delta variant spreads. China's government pledged to supply other nations with more vaccines that protect against Covid-19, targeting two billion exports for this year and calling for greater international cooperation as the Delta variant spreads.

title: Virgin Galactic Space Flight Tickets to Start at $450,000 a Seat
summary: Company previously sold tickets for space-tourism flights at up to $250,000 each. Virgin Galactic Holdings Inc. said it plans to charge consumers at least $450,000 for a seat on its space flights, setting a new price marker in the nascent space-tourism industry.

title: Schools Look for Help From AI Teacher's Assistants
summary: Researchers are developing artificial intelligence aimed at keeping students engaged and saving educators' time. Author

title: Trump's New Florida Gig Requires Suspension of Disbelief
summary: Former president makes way for a new star at Disney World but gets his own makeover. Donald Trump returned to a Florida venue this week where he has spoken countless times, but the former president stood silently in the back row as the completely masked crowd listened to other famous politicians. Chief among them was President Biden, who recited the oath of office.

title: Five Best: Books by Travelers-in-Residence
summary: Selected by Thomas Swick, the author, most recently, of 'The Joys of Travel.'. By Gerald Brenan (1957)

title: Children's Books: Picturing Love
summary: Four big-hearted picture books that celebrate tender family attachment.. When you read a picture book to a small child, that child hears your voice speaking the words that the author has written. This is a tautology, you might think: "Well, of course if I am reading aloud, it is my voice that the child is hearing." Yet beneath this statement of the obvious there's something wonderful. For when you read a picture book in which the author (or a character) expresses affection and tenderness, then the child hears not merely the loving words in the book, which is nice enough, but also those loving words spoken by you. For this reason, picture books about love have the happy effect of dispensing it.

title: A Closer Look
summary: Selections from 'Home Is Where the Heart Is' by Emma Dodd. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: 'In the Forest of No Joy' Review: Blood on the Tracks
summary: The French wanted a train line from African mines to the coast. The cost to Africans was misery and death.. Colonialism in French sub-Saharan Africa was state-sanctioned pillage conducted in the name of European civilization, an extractive enterprise designed to strip the land of its resources at rock-bottom cost. In the most benighted times, these resources included human beings sold into slavery. By the late 19th and early 20th centuries, however, the French Empire had come to focus almost entirely on raw materials, especially rubber and copper. Any infrastructure that France built in Central Africa had to enable their seaward dispatch to the metropole. If something didn't help transport goods of value from the African interior to the coast, it wasn't built.

title: Whatever Happened to the Friendly Skies?
summary: Disruptive passenger behavior is surging. Flight crews deserve much better.. More Americans are returning to air travel, and the mood is...edgy. The Journal recently detailed a survey of 5,000 flight attendants in which 85 percent of the respondents said they'd been forced to deal with unruly passengers in the past year. This week the Journal reported that the FAA has already investigated 628 episodes of disruptive passenger behavior in 2021-up from fewer than 150 in all of 2019.

title: Mysteries: 'The Turnout' Review
summary: A production of 'The Nutcracker' becomes something darker in a stage-set fable of ruthless competition.. Much of the drama in Megan Abbott's "The Turnout" (Putnam, 340 pages, $27) takes place in a ballet school that invites children, teens and parents into "the fairy tale that is dance."

title: 'FBOY Island,' 'Ex-Rated' and the Rise of Risqué Reality TV
summary: Resume Subscription. On reality dating shows, "Will you accept this rose?" has given way to another question: Will you take off your clothes?

summary: Things get better, however, around the time the divorce settlement is made final, a study finds. Actively trading securities in the run-up to a divorce can be detrimental to an individual investor's wealth, a draft research report finds.

title: China's Antitrust Regulator Planning to Fine Meituan About $1 Billion
summary: The penalty for allegedly abusing its dominant market position could be announced within weeks, people familiar with the matter say. SINGAPORE-China's antitrust regulator is preparing to impose a roughly $1 billion fine on food-delivery giant Meituan for allegedly abusing its dominant market position to the detriment of merchants and rivals, according to people familiar with the matter.

summary: Resume Subscription. TOKYO-With a haul of nine career medals, Allyson Felix was already one of the most revered Olympic track athletes in history. In the five years since the last Games she had become a mother and an activist-and turned 35 years old.

title: Business Groups Call on Biden to Restart China Trade Talks
summary: U.S. chamber, others say tariffs on Chinese imports are a drag on U.S. economy. WASHINGTON-Nearly three dozen of the nation's most influential business groups-representing retailers, chip makers, farmers and others-are calling on the Biden administration to restart negotiations with China and cut tariffs on imports, saying they are a drag on the U.S. economy.

title: News Corp Posts 30% Revenue Jump, Narrower Loss
summary: Revenue rise to $2.49 billion for June quarter was fueled by gains in its digital real-estate, book-publishing and Dow Jones units. News Corp reported a 30% increase in revenue for the June quarter, fueled by gains in its digital real-estate, book-publishing and Dow Jones units.

title: Zynga, Robinhood, Yelp, GoPro: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today
summary: Zynga slips as usage declines; Yelp jumps as it lifts its guidance. Dow futures were up while Nasdaq futures slipped after a monthly update on the state of the U.S. job market showed that the unemployment rate fell in July. Here's what we're watching before Friday's trading gets going.

title: Should the Delta Variant Change Your Decisions? Here's What Doctors Are Doing
summary: The rise in the Covid-19 variant's cases has people reassessing daily activities; doctors share what they are doing differently in their own lives. In little more than a week, Robert Wachter, chair of the department of medicine at the University of California, San Francisco, says his assessment of the risk posed by the Delta variant has changed-and he has changed his behavior accordingly.

title: The Olympic Velodrome's Man in Black
summary: Resume Subscription. IZU, Japan-Toshiaki Fushimi rides the banked track of the Olympic velodrome here every day, stern-faced and dressed in black, like he's on the most serious milk run in the world. He pedals slowly and precisely until he's zipping along the boards at more than 30 miles per hour.

title: 'Ted Lasso' Star Juno Temple on What She Learned from Jason Sudeikis
summary: Temple also discusses why she always buys lingerie for each role she plays: "It's my superhero cloak.". Actor Juno Temple fell asleep on her couch while watching the Emmy nominations broadcast last month. She found out that she'd received a nod for outstanding supporting actress in a comedy series only when she was woken up by an incoming FaceTime call from her agents. Temple, 32, plays Keeley in the Apple TV+ show Ted Lasso, about an American football coach (played by Jason Sudeikis, who is also a writer and executive producer on the show) who's hired to coach a British football team (meaning soccer) overseas, as part of a plan to sabotage the team by the former owner's ex-wife (Rebecca, played by Hannah Waddingham). In the show's first season, Temple's character transforms from a model-influencer-type WAG to Rebecca's empowering and lovable best friend.

title: How Mexican Gymnasts Leapt Into Olympic History at the Tokyo Games
summary: Resume Subscription. TOKYO-Rut Castillo's Olympic debut here at Ariake Gymnastics Centre Friday was set to Tom Holkenborg's "Never Give Up." The tune from the movie "Tomb Raider" wasn't just the backdrop to her hoop routine, but also very much the ethos of the gymnastics team that represented Mexico in the Tokyo Games.

summary: Investment giant also faces civil lawsuits from investors who took huge losses on its Structured Alpha funds. summary: Resume Subscription. MOSCOW-The smoke from the fires in Russia's northeast is so thick it has blotted out the sun, plunging swaths of the region into darkness during the brief summer.

summary: The Doctors Without Borders hospital will open in Kunduz, close to Taliban lines; U.S. has acknowledged it was bombed in error. WASHINGTON-The international aid group Doctors Without Borders is reopening a trauma hospital in northern Afghanistan, six years after a U.S. airstrike destroyed the building and killed more than 40 people, the organization said.

title: In Real Estate, Price Isn't Just a Number
summary: Solid second-quarter results from Zillow, Redfin did little to move their stock after their extraordinary run earlier this year. Bargains in real estate are exceedingly rare these days, but one corner of the market is well below its recent asking price. Shares of Zillow Group and Redfin Corp. are down an average 28% over the past six months, while shares of Opendoor are down more than 45%. Buyers should look before they leap.

title: Huawei Reports 38% Revenue Drop as U.S. Sanctions Bite
summary: Revenue declines deepen amid U.S. restrictions on chip supply, pressure on buyers. HONG KONG-China's Huawei Technologies Co. reported a 38% fall in quarterly revenue Friday, as the damage U.S. sanctions have done to its sales of smartphones and telecommunications equipment worsened.

title: An Ohio Factory's Test: Will Higher Wages Help More Than They Hurt?
summary: Resume Subscription. CLEVELAND-Charlie Braun long wondered whether paying higher wages would ease staffing shortages at his rubber parts factory, or simply push it into financial trouble. The Covid-19 pandemic provided a rare opportunity to experiment.

summary: Carvana has wiped away investors' fears around its path to profitability. It still faces some high-class problems.. Online used-car seller Carvana has been speeding past growth expectations for some time. Now it has arrived at a critical milestone at least a year earlier than anyone expected.

title: Eviction Moratorium's Renewal Squeezes Small Landlords
summary: Many individual property owners have struggled to collect monthly rent checks, and some have gone into forbearance on mortgages. This week's revival of the national eviction ban is sending landlords scrambling again to pay their debts, just when they thought they would be able to begin evicting tenants who are not paying rent.

summary: Resume Subscription. Soon he had to deal with something far more unusual.

title: Two Big Asian Tech IPOs Surge on Market Debuts
summary: Online businesses across the region are enjoying rapid growth, fueling investor appetite. Shares in a newly listed South Korean digital bank and an Indonesian e-commerce group both soared Friday, pointing to investor appetite for tech deals in emerging markets across Asia.

title: 'Mr. Corman' Review: Facing Life's Lessons
summary: Joseph Gordon-Levitt directs and stars as a dissatisfied fifth-grade teacher and aspiring composer in this Apple TV+ dramedy series set in the Covid-19 era. Billed though it is as comedy-drama, it's clear from the start of "Mr. Corman" (begins Friday, Apple TV+) that the laughs in this 10-episode series will be few but the smiles of recognition frequent. It's a testament to the complex charms of this series that those smiles are as often summoned by bleak moments as happier ones. Some of the most engaging aspects of this tale derive from the problems that arise when its hero, Josh Corman (Joseph Gordon-Levitt, who is also the show's creator, producer and director), undertakes efforts to pursue women-situations that yield some of the most hilarious moments. They're moments made still more enticing by the flow of pure venom that follows when characters' plans go awry. Things can go wrong on dates, everyone knows-some of them the most intimate kind of going wrong. And in the world "Mr. Corman" describes, there's not a lot of gracious forgiveness to spare at such times.

title: 'Happier Than Ever' by Billie Eilish Review: Growing Ups and Downs
summary: The teenage pop sensation's second album presents a matured take on the trials of stardom, but falters in its musical style..

title: 'Annette' Review: The Sparks Don't Fly
summary: Adam Driver and Marion Cotillard star as a celebrity couple with an unusual child in this offbeat musical, directed by Leos Carax, with an unmemorable pop-opera score by the Mael brothers' band. The French film director Leos Carax has always seemed plagued by contradictory impulses. He can't resist being transgressive-he was a charter member of what the critic James Quandt dubbed the "New French Extremity" of the late 20th century. He wants to remain relevant, though his best-loved film remains "Les Amants du Pont-Neuf" ("The Lovers on the Bridge"), which dates back to 1991. Occasionally, he allows his gift for creating poetically beautiful and architecturally elevated cinema to spill out across the screen. The thing that eludes Mr. Carax-as "Annette" so amply and painfully demonstrates-is balance.

title: Satyajit Ray: Maharajah of Movies
summary: The Criterion Channel celebrates what would have been the great Indian filmmaker's 100th birthday by streaming 16 of his features, both famous and lesser-known.

title: 'The Little Rascals' Review: Kids With Senior Status
summary: Some of the best episodes of Hal Roach's beloved comedy series about a gang of mischievous children have now been restored and released on Blu-ray. For nearly 100 years, children have grown up with Hal Roach's "Our Gang" series (aka the "Little Rascals"), little movies that-in the most endearing and funny way imaginable-capture how kids speak, think, understand, and, most important, interact with one another.

title: 'A Wild Note of Longing: Albert Pinkham Ryder and a Century of American Art' Review: An Enigmatic Painter Comes Into Focus
summary: An exhibition at the New Bedford Whaling Museum examines the visionary artist's work and traces his influence on Jackson Pollock and others.. New Bedford, Mass.

title: 'Abandoned: Expedition Shipwreck' Review: Delving Deep
summary: A new series on the Science Channel investigates the world's most historic-and forgotten-shipwrecks, including those that were the result of nuclear testing.. The 10-part series "Abandoned: Expedition Shipwreck" is like a tour of a haunted house, albeit one with a lot of room. And waves. Beneath the surface of seas, on the floors of oceans and even under the Saint Lawrence River lie secrets, ghost stories and, most important, wrecks. What the series promises is a search for those sunken ships, many of which have been largely lost to history, and the reasons they sank.

summary: This summer, gain a new perspective on the Games by seeing how artists, architects and even comedians have envisioned competition down the centuries..

summary: Most Popular News. Millions of people have quit their jobs this year, and many more are expected to join them.

title: SPAC Backed by Corvex, Casdin Near Deal for Drug-Price Startup EQRx
summary: The deal includes a $1.2 billion investment from a subsidiary of SoftBank, among others. A special-purpose acquisition company backed by a longtime life-sciences investor and a well-known shareholder activist has struck a deal to merge with a young pharmaceutical startup trying to slash drug prices.

title: The Smarter Way to Visit Great Smoky Mountains, America's Most Popular National Park
summary: On a return trip to Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a traveler learns from past mistakes and finds her own patch of euphoric solitude. Plus: Best strategies for beating the crowds at Yellowstone, Zion and the Grand Canyon.. I WAS STANDING near my husband, both of us perched carefully on the edge of Twentymile Creek Cascades, while a half-dozen light blue butterflies the size of nickels fluttered around our boots. We could hear the water rushing over rocks below us, the creek swollen from a late-summer storm we'd just barely missed. Around us, it felt as though the forest was breathing, and finally I realized we were, too. Deeply, fully breathing.

title: Will the U.S. Ever Go Metric? It Already Has, Sort Of
summary: The country has been creeping toward the metric system for decades, and is fully bilingual when it comes to discussing weights and measures. The U.S. never fully mandated the use of the meter, liter and gram, but for decades, the country has inched toward the metric system anyway.

title: Trump Sticks With Fundraising Gimmick Despite DOJ Crackdown
summary: Justice Department warns of 'misrepresentations' in appeals promising to multiply a donor's contribution. MATCHING-DONATION GIMMICKS from political campaigns have come under increased scrutiny from federal prosecutors looking to tamp down on misleading fundraising appeals-but former President Donald Trump continues to rely on the technique to woo small donors. Trump's official Save America fundraising committee is still sending appeals with subject lines like "400% impact" that promise to turn a $500 donation into a $2,500 one. Campaign-finance experts warn that the tactic is legally questionable.

title: Universities Face Student Lawsuits Over Covid-19 Vaccine Mandate
summary: Legal challenges represent a significant test of the government's power to press adults to get vaccinated. Hundreds of thousands of college and graduate students at public universities have been given a choice: Get fully vaccinated against Covid-19 or don't show up to campus in the fall.

title: Australia Takes Center Stage in Global Deals Spree
summary: Square's proposed takeover of Afterpay pushes Australian M&A to record high. SYDNEY-Australia's biggest airport is resisting a takeover. An American private equity firm wants to buy one of the country's main casino operators. And this week, Square Inc. agreed to buy Afterpay Ltd. , the largest locally listed tech company, for $29 billion.

title: China Tech Selloff Hits Hong Kong Hard
summary: Once market settles, financial hub is likely to win more Chinese IPOs. As China's technology giants struggle, few markets are suffering like Hong Kong. A rush of new listings could eventually soften the blow.

title: Wall Street Needs You to Go Shopping
summary: Spending figures are eye-popping now, but the profligacy will have to last well into 2022 if consumer-facing companies are to meet analysts' expectations. Before you buy shares in a company expected to benefit from the post-Covid consumer boom, ask yourself a question: Will you spend the money you saved during the pandemic?

title: China Telecom, Exiled From U.S., Prices $7 Billion-Plus Shanghai Offering
summary: The stock offering would be the world's biggest new listing in more than a year. One of China's big three telecommunications carriers set the price for a share sale in Shanghai in which it plans to raise about $7.3 billion, months after it was cut off from U.S. markets.

title: Infrastructure Bill to Add $256 Billion to Deficits, CBO Says
summary: Negotiators had argued that the cost of the legislation for new roads and bridges would be fully paid for. WASHINGTON-Congress's nonpartisan scorekeeper found that the roughly $1 trillion infrastructure bill would widen the federal budget deficit by $256 billion over 10 years, countering negotiators' claims that the price tag would be covered by new revenue and saving measures.

summary: Kuaishou Technology pulled Zynn from U.S. app stores, while Chinese state media attacked proliferation of harmful video-streaming content. The shares of Kuaishou Technology , the owner of a popular Chinese short-video platform that competes with ByteDance Ltd., tumbled 15% Thursday after the company took down a U.S. app and the sector it operates in was criticized by a state-media outlet.

title: Spirit Airlines Cancels Half of Thursday Flights as CEO Apologizes
summary: Budget carrier has canceled over 1,700 flights since Sunday. Spirit Airlines Inc. Chief Executive Ted Christie apologized for five days of flight cancellations that upended plans for thousands of people, saying the airline had struggled to resolve problems that spiraled out of control.

title: Lionel Messi, One of World's Top Soccer Players, to Leave Barcelona
summary: The club announced that La Liga rules on payrolls would prevent it from offering Messi a new contract. FC Barcelona spent much of the past year convincing itself that Lionel Messi would stay at the club. It was, after all, the only club he'd only ever known as a professional-the place where he'd transformed himself from undersized teenager to one of the greatest soccer players of all time.

title: Iraq War Repeal Gains Key GOP Support
summary: The House passed similar bipartisan legislation in June amid debate on president's latitude to send troops into combat. WASHINGTON-Ten Republican senators have signed on as co-sponsors of a bipartisan bill to repeal the 1991 and 2002 authorizations for use of military force in Iraq, a key threshold needed to overcome a Senate filibuster.

title: Former Executive With Collapsed Insurers Receives Five-Year Prison Sentence
summary: Scherr, who pleaded guilty last year to two criminal counts, was also ordered to pay $286 million in restitution. A former executive of a group of collapsed insurers was sentenced to five years in federal prison and ordered to pay $286 million in restitution.
